marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Anthony Digges was a captain of the schooner Betsey, and resident of Washington, North Carolina.
Pages from the account book of Digges, a sea captain plying the coast of North Carolina; an agreement for the sale of a schooner; and letters to Digges concerning maritime affairs.
Matthew Dickinson was head of the Franklin Academy at Louisburg, North Carolina, and a lawyer.
Letters and papers of Matthew Dickinson concerning personal affairs. They are mostly accounts and records of money borrowed and loaned. There is a price list from a Raleigh book- dealer, 1806.

One section of this volume records the sale of goods salvaged from the wrecked ship CULLODEN. The other section contains the records of the Sissiboo Baptist Church and a note on African-American Baptists in Nova Scotia.
Samuel Dickinson was a resident of Edenton, North Carolina.
Letters concerning marketing of shingles; cost of boat construction at Norfolk, Virginia; lumber for the West Indian market; and payments to the legatees of Robert Smith of Edenton, North Carolina.
Charles Knapp Dillaway (1804-1889) was an antiquarian, author, and a resident of Roxbury, Massachusetts.
Letters concerning the American Antiquarian Society.
Joseph Dickinson was a resident of Franklin County, Virginia.

Letters from Nolen and Griffith Dickinson on travels from Virginia to Missouri. Other letters of the Dickinson family are of John P. and Joseph Wright referring to the hard times and quoting the price of cotton and tobacco. In a letter of 1838, Wm. A. Dickinson suggested to Joseph Wright that they try growing Chinese mulberry trees for sale, saying that a great many people in eastern Virginia and to the north were making silk. A letter written by Hester and Lancaster of Marion, Alabama in 1854 stated that they were selling slaves very slowly since the trade in that state was very dull.
John James Dillard was a resident of Elk Furnace (Nelson Co.), Va.

Letters and papers of the Dillard family consisting of a few items of political correspondence including a letter on the presidential election of 1840; letters from the Civil War describing campaigns in Virginia; family correspondence discussing the law, anesthetics, the Democratic Party, black servants, and a description of Philadelphia, Pa.; and financial papers relating to the purchase and shipping of gunpowder from Connecticut by Alfred Woodroof.

Asbury Dickins (1780-1861) was a publisher, bookseller, chief clerk in the State Department and Treasure Department, and secretary of the United States Senate. Dickins was a resident of Halifax County, North Carolina, Philadelphia, Great Britain, and Washington, D.C.

Letters of Asbury Dickens (1780-1861) to Matthew Carey regarding census figures and a circular concerned with the distribution of the works of John Adams. Included also is a personal letter from Archibald Dixon.
Joseph Dickinson was a partner in the slave trading firm of Dickinson and Hill, and a resident of Richmond, Virginia.
Correspondence of the slave-trading firm concerning the slave market and prices of slaves.
Hider D. Dickens was a Confederate soldier from North Carolina.
Letters of a Confederate soldier imprisoned at Elmira, N.Y., and a few family letters, including two from Dickens' niece who was a student at Greensboro Female College (Greensboro, N.C.), 1876-1877.
Jeannie A. Dickson was a writer, and the daughter of Samuel Henry Dickson of Charleston, S.C., and New Orleans, La., physician and author.

Papers consisting primarily of letters and poems of Paul Hamilton Hayne, George Herbert Sass, and John R. Thompson. Hayne's letters include his opinion of Northern magazines, views on politics, literary production of contemporary Southern writers, and the condition of Georgia after the Civil War. Material connected with Sass is largely poetry, most of which was later published. Thompson's letters include comments on current literary productions and criticisms of Jeannie Dickson's work. One letter is from John Russell.

Mentioned in the collection are: Henry Dickson Bruns, John Bruns, [George] Washington Cable, James Wood Davidson, Charles E.A. Gayarré, Gervais Robinson, William Gilmore Simms, Frances C. (Fisher) Tiernan's "Valerie Aylmer," and the works of Richard D. Blackmore, Charles Reade, and Sir Walter Scott.
James F. Dillard was a Confederate soldier from Washington (Wilkes Co.), Ga.

Family letters of a Confederate soldier describing a trip from Georgia to Richmond, Va., via Charleston, S.C., 1861, and explaining removal of camp sites from Fredericksburg, Va., because of general poverty and poor soil in the area. Dillard also mentions his experiences while going to the front lines in 1861, and his parole in 1865.
Hubert Anton Casimir Dilger (1836-1911) was a Union artillery officer, a resident of Franklin, Virginia, and achieved fame under the name Leatherbreeches.
Papers of the captain of the Mountain Howitzer Battery, 1st Battalion, West Virginia Light Artillery, concerning the transfer of troops and supplies to his command.
Charles Augustus Ropes Dimon was a Union army officer, rising to brigadier general, from Massachusetts. Dimon was also a resident of Mobile, Alabama.

Military papers and correspondence while Dimon was in Mobile, Ala., describing the operations of the U.S.S. Currituck, 1864; discussing the activities of the 86th U.S. Regiment (Colored), 1867; and an order from General John Pope removing the mayor and chief of police of Mobile, Ala., for failure to maintain order, 1867. Included is a resolution of the Mobile Democratic Club appealing for African American votes for Seymour and Blair. Also several papers relating to fugitives from justice.
Edgar Dinsmore was an African American Union soldier from Connecticut.

Letters from Edgar Dinsmore, an African American soldier in the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment, to Carrie Drayton, Brooklyn, N.Y., commenting on campaign activities, an anticipated early Union victory, and the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
Published in Richard B. Harwell, ed., "Edgar Dinsmore Letters," Journal of Negro History, XXV (July, 1940), 363-371.
Anna Elizabeth Dickinson (1842-1932) was an orator, lecturer, an advocate for the abolition of slavery and for women's rights, and a resident of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
The collection includes letters to Thomas Jefferson Durant and J.B. Hayes concerning speaking engagements; and a letter to Thomas J. Prase concerning articles for publication.
